newsitem.title: USA: Talks continue at GM plant as strike deadline passes.
newsitem.headline: Talks continue at GM plant as strike deadline passes.

text.p: A midnight deadline at General Motors Corp.'s Cadillac assembly plant passed without a strike as bargainers continued talks early on Saturday in an effort to reach a deal for a new local labour contract.

United Auto Workers Local 22 and its 3,600 members were poised to unleash the seventh strike this year against the auto giant, a walkout that could disrupt the launch of GM's important new 1998 Seville flagship sedan.

Workers streamed out of the plant in the Hamtramck, Michigan, enclave in Detroit after the 11:59 p.m. EDT Friday deadline and began picketing, but union officials said talks were continuing and no strike had been declared.
"We have not been notified that there has been an end to these talks," said Local 22 recording secretary Karl Burnett. "It is believed they're still at it."
GM spokesman Paul Spadafora said the union had not informed the company of a strike.
The Cadillac plant on the Detroit-Hamtramck border does not normally build cars on Saturday, so any walkout declared over the weekend would not affect production until Monday.

As in six strikes this year and numerous strike threats, the UAW demanded more jobs at the plant to replace retiring workers and ease a growing workload. GM resisted such moves, maintaining that it needs to shrink its workforce to become competitive with Ford Motor Co., Chrysler Corp., and Japanese automakers.
The plant on the Detroit-Hamtramck border is the only assembly site for Cadillac's Seville, DeVille and Eldorado models, but dealers have ample supplies of 1997 models of the cars.

But a prolonged walkout could disrupt GM's ambitious plans to position the '98 Seville as a world-class luxury car that can compete head-to-head with Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Lexus. GM will unveil the car next month in the German automakers' backyard, at the international auto show in Frankfurt, Germany.
Cadillac plans to build a right-hand-drive version of the car and hopes to export the Seville all over the world in a bid to shed its stuffy, land-yacht image.

A seven-week strike that started in April at GM's Oklahoma City assembly plant disrupted the launch of GM's mid-size Chevrolet Malibu and Oldsmobile Cutlass sedans, which were viewed as critical to GM's efforts to regain market share.

"The most damaging thing about the strike in Oklahoma City was that it forced the company to relaunch the Malibu," said Schroder Wertheim & Co. auto analyst John Casesa. "If the strike had not happened, that car would have better awareness and better sales."
GM sold a respectable 12,996 Malibus in July, but that still fell short of the Corsicas and Berettas it replaced, which had sales of 15,698 units for the month.
Analysts also worry that consumers' attention will be drawn away from the car by Honda's launch of an all-new Accord this fall.
The strikes have been costly to GM, cutting second-quarter profits by $490 million and reducing its share of the domestic car and light truck market well below GM's 1997 goal of 33 percent.

The automaker also said on Friday that a three-month walkout at a Pontiac, Michigan, truck plant and a six-day strike at a Warren, Michigan, transmission plant, forced it to cut its third-quarter production schedule by 20,000 vehicles.

A walkout at the Cadillac plant walkout would not have a widespread impact on GM's North American production operations since it is a final assembly plant. But it could force layoffs at plants that produce parts and components for it, such as engines and seats.
